title: 110_s2267
content: The "Americans Giving care to Elders (AGE) Act of 2007" is also known as the SEC. 25E, which provides a credit for eldercare expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The SEC. 25E allows a tax credit for eldercare expenses based on the applicable percentage of expenses paid by an individual with qualifying individuals. The applicable percentage decreases as adjusted gross income exceeds $120,000. Definitions for qualifying individuals and eldercare expenses are provided. Expenses related to eldercare are defined as amounts paid for the care of a qualifying individual, such as a parent or ancestor who needs help with daily activities. Eldercare expenses incurred at care centers outside the taxpayer's home must comply with state or local regulations to be considered for tax credit. The tax credit for eldercare expenses is limited to $6,000 per year. Care centers must provide care for more than six individuals and receive payment for services to qualify for the credit. The tax credit for eldercare expenses is limited to $6,000 per year and is subject to exclusions. Payments to related individuals, such as dependents or children under 19, are not eligible for the credit. The term 'taxable year' refers to the taxpayer's year in which the service is performed. To claim a credit, identifying information of the service provider must be included on the return. Failure to provide this information will result in the disallowance of the credit. The taxpayer must exercise due diligence in providing required information to claim the credit. The taxpayer identification number of qualifying individuals must be included on the return. Married couples must file a joint return to claim the credit. No double benefit is allowed if a credit is already claimed under another section. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this section. The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item after section 25D. Section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code allows for expenses related to eldercare. Conforming amendments include changes to sections 213(e) and 6213(g)(2) to incorporate eldercare expenses. The amendments made by this section, including the insertion of "25E," after "24," in subparagraph (L), will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. The National Family Caregiver Support Program funding is increased to $250,000,000 for fiscal years 2008-2011. Additionally, a National Resource Center on Family Caregiving is established under the Older Americans Act of 1965. The National Resource Center on Family Caregiving is established under the Older Americans Act of 1965. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award a grant to a public or private nonprofit entity to establish the Center, which aims to support family caregivers. The National Resource Center on Family Caregiving, established under the Older Americans Act of 1965, aims to support family caregivers by identifying best practices, providing policy updates, partnering with organizations, offering educational programs, and maintaining a searchable database of caregiver resources. $12,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2011. The National Resource Center on Family Caregiving, established under the Older Americans Act of 1965, is authorized to receive $12,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2011. Technical amendments are made to sections 431(a) and 432(a) of the Act.
